Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History: Organization, expansion, and digitization of the larval fish collection at the Virginia Institute of Marine Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the Virginia Institute of Marine Science Nunnally Ichthyology Collection to safeguard this rare resource and preserve it for current and future scientific research. Among the specimens targeted is a large and important collection of larval fishes derived from collections made worldwide. This larval fish collection was collected as part of oceanographic studies and represent time series over broad geographic ranges. Thus, the collection of larval fishes lends itself to studying, for example, the effect of the physical environment or anthropogenic-induced environmental changes on larval fish communities over time and across a range of habitats. This project has three main goals: 1) improve storage of specimens to ensure long-term preservation; 2) identify specimens and increase their utility for research and teaching; and 3) catalog specimens and link associated environmental data and images in a publicly accessed digital database.

The proper storage, identification, and digitization of these samples will secure them and increase their value. The researchers will organize workshops to introduce students, collection managers, and other professionals to the study, identification, and care of larval fish specimens. These workshops will offer intensive training and will be led by prominent larval fish experts. This award will also contribute to graduate student training, serving as the foundation of a student?s research and training in curatorial best practices. The results of this project will be communicated to the general public through seminars, displays, social media outlets, and tours organized by the collections staff. Additional information is available at: http://www.vims.edu/research/facilities/fishcollection/index.php.

Institution.Name: College of William & Mary Virginia Institute of Marine Science

POR.DRECONTENT:
Early life history stages of fishes are of key importance for many types of studies, from oceanographic and ecological studies to systematics and evolution. However, these specimens can be logistically difficult to deal with in natural history collections due to issues ranging from identification to storage. As a result, there are relatively few natural history collections that actively develop and maintain these important resources.

The Virginia Institute of Marine Science Nunnally Ichthyology Collection maintains a large (c. 51,267 lots) previously uncatalogued collection of marine larval fishes. Using resources secured and developed by this project, the Nunnally Ichthyology Collection was able to safeguard this rare resource and preserve it for current and future scientific research. This larval fish collection was collected as part of oceanographic studies and represent time series over broad geographic ranges, including the Chesapeake Bay and the Northwest Atlantic, the South-Central Atlantic, the Central Pacific, and the Southern oceans. Thus, the collection of larval fishes lends itself to studying, for example, the effect of the physical environment or anthropogenic-induced environmental changes on larval fish communities over time and across a range of habitats. This project had three main goals: 1) improve storage of specimens to ensure long-term preservation; 2) identify specimens and increase their utility for research and teaching; and 3) catalog specimens and link associated environmental data and images in a publicly accessed digital database.

The proper storage, identification, and digitization of these samples increased their value. The project involved improving the storage of specimens, many of which are currently contained in jars and vials that are either boxed up and unsearchable or are loosely stored in poorly constructed wooden trays. We transferred specimens from formalin to ethanol in new, tightly sealing vials. Over 20,000 lots were stabilized (approximately half of which are unidentified, multispecies lots); identification and cataloging are ongoing. A lab within the collection building was renovated and vials of larvae were moved to high-quality cabinets for long-term storage. In this project, specimens were identified and the collection was digitized. We catalogued and linked raw collection and associated environmental data, images, and other information related to the electronic record. A total of 10,904 lots (126,535 specimens) were identified and cataloged during this project.

We hosted three workshops at VIMS based on this project. Two of these workshops (held in October, 2015, and June 2016) were each two weeks in duration and concerned larval fish identification and collection curation. Participants (13 in 2015 and 14 in 2016), including collection managers, researchers, students, and collection volunteers from throughout the US, as well as several international institutions, worked alongside world-renowned larval fish taxonomists (from the Australian Museum; National Natural History Museum, Paris; NOAA Fisheries; and the Smithsonian Institution among other institutions) to learn identification of larval fishes. In 2015, a total of 4,694 individual fishes in 811 lots, comprising 100 families (nine of which were new additions to the VIMS Collection) were identified; in 2016 in excess of 10,000 individuals (c. 2000 lots) were identified during the workshop. Pre- and post-workshop assessments were conducted to determine workshop success. A repeated theme in many comments on post-workshop assessments echoed the importance of the hands-on nature of both workshops, with immediate practice in identification of a broad diversity of larval fishes under the watchful eyes of internationally recognized larval fish taxonomists. At the end of the workshop participants felt significantly more prepared to identify larvae, access identification resources, store/organize collections, digitize specimens, and clear and stain larval fishes.

A two-day workshop on the Specify database software was conducted at VIMS by Andy Bentley (KU), and included nine participants from institutions across the US. The VIMS Nunnally Ichthyology Collection was in the process of migrating its database to this software, and most participants in this workshop were involved with working with the larval fish collection or other parts of the collection.

This project has provided opportunities for involvement of the general public through volunteer opportunities. In addition, two undergraduate students completed research credits working with the larval fish collection. One of these students was recruited as a Ph.D. student by Hilton and Steinberg to work on larval fishes from Antarctica for his dissertation.

The results and activities of the project have been broadly disseminated to the research community through presentations at the Early Life History section of the American Fisheries Society, the American Society of Ichthyologists and Herpetologists, and the Society of Preservation of Natural History Collections. Aspects of this project were also included in articles appearing on the VIMS website, regional newspapers (Daily Press) and included in other institutional advancement media (e.g., “Impact”, a newsletter sent to potential institutional donors).
